title: Is the circumference of a circle always irrational? What does the circumference of a circle being irrational mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is the circumference of a circle always irrational? What does the circumference of a circle being irrational mean?  Contrary to some rather misguided and ill-informed responses to this question, no of course it’s not always Irrational[1] . A combination of Euclid and Archimedes (in that order) proved in antiquity that the ratio of a circle’s circumference ([math]c[/math]) to its diameter ([math]d[/math]) [and thereby obviously its radius ([math]r=\frac{d}{2}[/math])] was invariant, with the figure in question being between [math]3\frac{1}{10}[/math] and [math]3\frac{1}{5}[/math] [2]. Much, much later (1706), William Jones[3] coined the usage of the Greek letter for ‘p’, [math]\pi[/math], to denote this constant and it stuck. So that means our mysterious constant can be written as: [math]\dfrac{c}{2r}=\pi\tag*{}[/math] Which we can rearrange as: [math]c=2\pi r\hspace{5mm}(1)\tag*{}[/math]  In a 1768 paper, German Mathematician Johann Heinrich Lambert proved that [math]\pi[/math] was an Irrational Number. Amongst other things, this means that if the radius of a circle is a Rational Number[4] then its circumference is indeed Irrational. To see why, if instead the circumference was Rational, then there would exist an Integer[5] , [math]a[/math], and a Natural Number[6] , [math]b,[/math] such that: [math]c=\dfrac{a}{b}\tag*{}[/math] But then, if our radius is also Rational, we have an Integer, [math]e[/math], and a Natural Number, [math]f[/math], such that: [math]r=\dfrac{e}{f}\tag*{}[/math] And by (1) we have: [math]\dfrac{a}{b}=2\pi\dfrac{e}{f}\tag*{}[/math] Rearranging we get: [math]\pi=\dfrac{af}{2be}\tag*{}[/math] Which is obviously Rational, a contradiction. So we have shown our result [math]\blacksquare[/math].  But the radius does not have to be Rational. In particular if we set: [math]r=\dfrac{q}{\pi}\tag*{}[/math] Where q is any Rational Number, then the circumference will be: [math]c=2q\tag*{}[/math] which is clearly a Rational Number.  Tired of having sand kicked in your face by people who know more about [math]\pi[/math]? Read The Irrational Ratio and it will be you doing the kicking[math]^{[a]}[/math]. Note [a] The author does not condone the kicking of sand. No sand was harmed in the writing of this answer. Footnotes[1] The Irrational Ratio[2] Peter James Thomas's answer to Pi is the ratio of the circumference and the diameter. Pi comes even in the formula of circumference. Sure, the circumference of circle must be irrational. The circumference of circle is given by 2*pi*r ,where r is the radius of circle. Since pi is an irrational number and irrational*rational=irrational So, circumference must be irrational. There is no any proper method to measure the length of a curve. The one of the method is by using a thread and placing it exactly on the curve and make it straight again to measure its length. This method has some ambiguity. Circles are curve at each and every point on their curvature. If we place the thread on its curvature, it must become slightly straight at any point because points are very small and we can not visualize it. Thus, the circumference of circle being irrational means it can not be calculated exactly.

It is pointless to say whether the circumference of a circle is rational or irrational. It is like asking whether my weight is rational or irrational. However, it is understood that you are asking whether the measure of the circumference of a circle may be irrational. It depends upon the unit of measure you adopt. Suppose you have a zero-thick non graduated tape that exactly wraps around a circle. Now define the length of the tape the unit of length. Your circle has a rational circumference. But if you now measure the diameter of that circle in terms of the unit you just defined, you cannot express the diameter, I beg a pardon, the measure of the diameter ;) in p/q form. Hence, the measure of the diameter becomes irrational. Conversely, if you define the measure of the diameter the unit of measure, then surely the circumference would become irrational. There is no circle the ratio of whose circumference to diameter is rational. Hope, you got my point.

Not if the diameter of the circle is irrational in the right way :) The circumference of a circle is pi (an irrational number) x the diameter. So if the diameter of a circle is rational then the circumference is irrational. BUT: Take a bar of length exactly one metre. Bend it into a circle.You now have a circle of diameter 1/pi metres (an irrational value) ; but its circumference is still 1 metre; that’s rational. “The circumference of a circle being irrational” means no more or less than any length (or any number) being irrational. It means the length (or in general the value) cannot be characterised by dividing one integer (whole number) by another.

Is the circumference of a circle always irrational? No, if the radius is [math]\frac{k}{2\pi}[/math] the circumference will be [math]k[/math]. You can choose [math]k[/math] to be rational. From a practical point of view, rationality or irrationality are irrelevant. All measurements involve measurement error so there are no practical implications. If the radius of a theoretical circle is rational, the circumference will be irrational. But there is no such thing in practice, and the exact radius of a real circle is meaningless. You can’t measure exactly.

No, they can be any positive number, rational, irrational, or integer. After all, they are nothing more than lengths of circles, and just like lengths of anything they can be any positive number at all. There’s nothing remarkable about a linear distance of exactly 3 inches, and correspondingly there is nothing remarkable about a circle whose circumference is exactly 3 inches. Now if you want to talk about the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter, that’s a different story.

No, either the diameter of a circle or the circumference of a circle could be rational, but they can't both be. The ratio of two rational numbers must be rational. However, suppose the circumference of a circle is 3 units. Then, there must be some diameter d units such that 3 units = d units * pi In particular, d units = 3 units/pi

If you had a radius of [math]\frac{1}{\pi}[/math] for instance then the circumference would be rational. if the radius is rational the circumference will always be irrational. If the radius is irrational the circumference might be rational.

No. If the diameter of a circle is rational number divided by pi, the circumference will be rational, since it is equal to pi times the diameter.

Circumference (C) equals 2πr, so any rational number q, divided by π (q/π) taken to be the radius will do this: C = 2π(q/π) = 2q Knowing that the product of two rational numbers is rational, 2q is rational.
